title: Final Mastery Assessment: HS Geometry
description: Comprehensive end-of-course assessment covering all four quarters of HS Geometry: Foundations & Angles, Triangles, Congruence, Right Triangles, Polygons, Circles, Similarity, 3D Geometry, and Coordinate Geometry.

remediationResources.reteachFocus: Alternate interior, alternate exterior, corresponding, co-interior (same-side) angle pairs; setting equal or supplementary based on type
Interior sum 180°, exterior angle = sum of remote interior, working backwards from angle expressions
SSS (3 sides), SAS (2 sides + included angle), ASA (2 angles + included side); identify the shared/reflexive elements
a²+b²=c², identify the hypotenuse (longest, opposite right angle), recognize common triples: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, 7-24-25
45-45-90: legs equal, hyp=leg√2. 30-60-90: short:long:hyp = x:x√3:2x. Always identify which side you know first
SOH-CAH-TOA: sin=opp/hyp, cos=adj/hyp, tan=opp/adj. Draw triangle, label sides relative to the angle
Parallelogram hierarchy: opp sides/angles ≅, consec supplementary, diags bisect. Rectangle: diags ≅. Rhombus: diags ⊥ and bisect angles
Arc = (θ/360)×2πr, fraction of circumference; working backwards to find θ or r
Inscribed = half central, semicircle→90°, inscribed quad opposite angles supplementary
Corresponding sides proportional, scale factor k, area ratio = k², AA~/SSS~/SAS~ theorems
GM = √(a×b), altitude rule: h²=p×q, leg rule: leg²=(adjacent seg)(hyp)
V=Bh, identify base shape first; cylinder V=πr²h; always check units
V=(1/3)Bh for pyramids/cones, V=(4/3)πr³ for spheres; 1/3 relationship with prism/cylinder
(x-h)²+(y-k)²=r², signs opposite center, r² not r on right side

problems.question: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. Alternate interior angles measure (3x + 12)° and (5x - 8)°. Find x and both angle measures.
problems.answer: Alternate interior angles are congruent: 3x+12 = 5x-8 → 20 = 2x → x = 10. Both angles = 3(10)+12 = 42°. Check: 5(10)-8 = 42° ✓.

problems.question: A triangle has angles (2x + 5)°, (3x - 10)°, and (x + 35)°. Find all three angles and classify the triangle.
Can sides of length 7, 11, and 19 form a triangle? Justify.
problems.answer: Triangle inequality: the two shorter sides must sum to more than the longest. 7 + 11 = 18 < 19. No, these cannot form a triangle.

problems.question: Given: AB ≅ DE, ∠A ≅ ∠D, AC ≅ DF. Name the congruence postulate and write the congruence statement.
problems.answer: Two sides and the included angle between them are congruent → SAS. △ABC ≅ △DEF.

problems.question: A right triangle has legs of 9 and 40. Find the hypotenuse.
In a 30-60-90 triangle, the hypotenuse is 16. Find the short leg and the long leg.
In a right triangle, sin(θ) = 12/13. Find cos(θ) and tan(θ).
problems.answer: sin = opp/hyp = 12/13 → opp = 12, hyp = 13. Adjacent = √(13²-12²) = √(169-144) = √25 = 5. cos(θ) = adj/hyp = 5/13. tan(θ) = opp/adj = 12/5. (5-12-13 triple.)

problems.question: Find each interior angle of a regular 15-sided polygon.
In parallelogram ABCD, the diagonals intersect at E. AE = 3x + 2 and CE = 5x - 6. Find x and AE.
problems.answer: Diagonals bisect each other: AE = CE → 3x+2 = 5x-6 → 8 = 2x → x = 4. AE = 3(4)+2 = 14. Check: CE = 5(4)-6 = 14 ✓.

problems.question: A circle has radius 10. Find the arc length for a central angle of 108°.
An inscribed angle intercepts an arc of 124°. Find the inscribed angle measure.
Find the area of a sector with central angle 90° and radius 6.
△ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor 2:5. If AB = 8, find DE.
Find the geometric mean of 6 and 24.
A cone has radius 5 and height 12. Find the volume in terms of π.
A sphere has radius 9. Find the surface area in terms of π.
Write the equation of a circle with center (2, -3) and passing through the point (6, 0).

ANALYSIS: A right triangle has vertices at A(0, 0), B(8, 0), and C(0, 6). (a) Find the lengths of all three sides. (b) Find the area. (c) Find the coordinates of the midpoint of the hypotenuse. (d) Show that the midpoint of the hypotenuse is equidistant from all three vertices.
problems.answer: (a) AB = 8, AC = 6, BC = √(64+36) = √100 = 10. (b) Area = (1/2)(8)(6) = 24 sq units. (c) Midpoint of BC: M = ((8+0)/2, (0+6)/2) = (4, 3). (d) MA = √(16+9) = 5. MB = √(16+9) = 5. MC = √(16+9) = 5. All equal to 5 (half the hypotenuse), confirming the midpoint of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equidistant from all three vertices.
